page.title: 17SLEDGING ON THE SANDHILLS
page.content: On snowy winter afternoons the sandhills overlooking the promenade at New Brighton are swarming with people with sledges. All along the sandy slopes are brown streaks reaching down to road level showing where the smoothest and fastest routes have been found.Beside them small figures trudge back up to the top of the hills ready for the next few seconds of excitement. Sledges vary from new,light,plastic shells to heavy, homemade wooden "tanks" which can hardly be pulled up the slopes.But for those without sledges plastic bags,sheets of polythene or even car inner-tubes provide exciting,if erratic,rides.The sparkling snow,dotted with moving shapes,looks even whiter against the steel-grey of the sea beyond the promenade wall.
